Title: Why is $A^TA$ invertible if $A$ has independent columns?
AcceptedAnswer:
Consider the following:
$$A^TAx=\mathbf 0$$
Here, $Ax$, an element in the range of $A$, is in the null space of $A^T$. However, the null space of $A^T$ and the range of $A$ are orthogonal complements, so $Ax=\mathbf 0$. If $A$ has linearly independent columns, then $Ax=\mathbf 0 \implies x=\mathbf 0$, so the null space of $A^TA=\{\mathbf 0\}$. Since $A^TA$ is  a square matrix, this means $A^TA$ is invertible.
